example.text: It's so important that we provide our nation's children with the support they need to succeed and live productive lives. I was glad to recently introduce bipartisan legislation with Senator Susan Collins (R-ME) to support children's access to mental health.

As Chair of the Senate Armed Services Subcommittee on Readiness and Management Support, I'm glad to have helped secure resources for many Virginia priorities through this bill, including: Providing a 4.6% pay raise for military servicemembers and Department of Defense (DOD) civilian workforce; Increasing servicemembers' access to mental health resources; Directing the DOD to reevaluate how it calculates the Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) and raising BAH in high-cost areas; Improving oversight of privatized military housing; and Strengthening protections for victims of sexual assault. I'm also proud that the bill will authorize more than $295 million for 15 military construction projects and strengthen Virginia's water infrastructure in Western Lee County and Norfolk Harbor.
Look at Japan. We fought a war against Japan, a devastating war.
Learn more about the Investing in Infant and Early Childhood Mental Health Act here>>> I'll continue working to expand access to mental health services. I look forward to keeping in touch.

After hearing their feedback, I worked to craft the annual defense authorization act-legislation that will bolster our national security and benefit Virginia's defense community and shipbuilding industry. Today, the Senate passed that bill on a bipartisan basis.

Specifically, this bill would reauthorize the Infant and Early Childhood Mental Health (IECMH) program , which provides grants for early intervention mental health programs and treatments for children from birth up to 12 years of age who have experienced trauma, are exhibiting the first signs of mental or behavioral health challenges, or are at high risk for mental health issues. Without action by Congress, the program's funding could soon run out, so I'll be pushing to pass this bill ASAP.
